text: <@U04BD6KB1>: socialism doesnt work, the only thing I hate more than state sphagettis is socialism. I lived through it and trust its the worst possible system to live under… (we got free when I was 3 years old..)
and society NEEDS inequality: <http://www.paulgraham.com/inequality.html>
and I am with you that the second is more likely (and already happening)
<@U03SSL0FM>: it’s good to have you back
watch this: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7Pq-S557XQU>

:simple_smile:

attachments.title: Robots threaten these 8 jobs
attachments.text: Are you a lawyer or a marketer? Robots and powerful algorithms are likely to disrupt jobs in these eight formerly-stable career fields.

text: I was forced to become active by mixonic :smile:
I am on a mission to stop state sphagettis :smile:
<@U03SSL0FM>: are you going to comment on the RFC?
it seems popular
you’ll have to make your case very clearly
and diplomatically (casting no aspersions here)

<@U03SSL0FM>: the term “socialism” is 100% dead but what about some of the social aims of socialism exerting an influence on capitalism … they’ll call it the “new normal” or “social capitalism” or some other easier to swallow banner.
I think the problem is that robotics will force another wave of value reductions on human physical labour (centralized physical labour already largely discounted)
and AI will substantially reduce value reductions in intellectual labour
the old pattern of job destruction creating better jobs (the mantra for late 20th century) will be hard to repeat
<@U04BD6KB1>: have you read Capital in the  21st Century?
i have it purchased on my kindle but haven’t read it
:simple_smile:
working through it at the moment
it’s very good
not got into the predictive section of the book yet
he’s still laying the groundwork for this theories
i do know that he received a pretty harsh round of criticism after the initially very positive reception but actually I don’t know that the nature of the criticism was
doomsayers do have a tendency to be respected early and then the harshness of message is beaten down in a second wave :wink:
personally i feel its critical we find an economic model for social justice
as economic optimisation is an unstoppable force
yes, and taking environmental capital seriously too
and the traditional inefficiencies which unintentially provided refuge are going away
(that is what they call it, right? “environmental capital”)
well i’m not sure how universally that term is used but it makes sense to me
yeah, accounting for trees and stuff in the economic model
(you can tell I know my stuff, right?)
I think economists have started to come to terms with “social capital” (aka, trust versus corruption) as a measurable (or potentially) measurable thing
environmental concern and social concern just need to be codified as costs or they’ll be overrun
<@U04BD6KB1>: do you ever get along to the public lectures at LSE?
but this sort of artificial/indirect costing is very hard and not sure it has much precedent
no. are there any in particular that you’d recommend?
I’ve seen a bunch of good stuff in the past
subscribe to the newsletter and they give you plenty of notice of upcoming speakers
<http://jeffsachs.org/> was my favourite so far
and Slavoj Zizek of course :simple_smile:
Sachs was absolutely awesome
well next time your considering a talk let me know … i’m interested in the space
